R. H. STANTON.
THOS. J. THROOP

STANTON & THROOP,
ATTORNEYS AT LAW,
Maysville, Ky, Aug 30th 1861
Dear Col.

A young man in our city named Benj: Clark who keeps a small grocery store in the lower end of town was fined in two cases in our Circuit Court, for selling liquor without license. He is a young man just commencing life, knows very little about the law. & the fines against him in these hard times, are exceedingly onerous, & will almost ruin him to pay. He will not violate the law again, as he assures me, & will keep to its strict letter. He has petitioned the Governor for a remittance
of his fines, amounting in all to $100 -- WIll you be kind enough to speak a good word to the Governer for him, for I do think it is a case executive interference & try these fines remitted. The will be a sufficient lesson to this young gentleman to restrain him in future. Your kindness will be duly appreciated by him, & will also be considered a personal favor to me.
Your family are all well, Pretty times here, & the "Union" men are many of them becoming heartily sick of their party action, in trying to Kentucky in civil stife. Let me hear from you soon.
